post.title: Eurosummer
post.subtitle: Or how I learned to stop worrying and love the monoculture
post.description: Or how I learned to stop worrying and love the monoculture
post.truncated_body_text: Yesterday I turned 29 years old! In the last year, I wrote about AI and economic divides in San Francisco, learned to shoot a fully-manual camera, created my own inflation index, and savored the slow route. In today’s inbox, I compiled some stray reflections on my own European travel.

post.title: Echoes of Palme: A Return to Swedish Politics.
post.description: Returning to Sweden after more than a decade away and several sporadic visits feels like re-learning a language I used to know by heart.
post.truncated_body_text: Returning to Sweden after more than a decade away and several sporadic visits feels like re-learning a language I used to know by heart. I was born here in the late 90s, but my memories are a collage of impressions from a child or teenager’s perspective. The adult language of society, particularly its politics, is something I now have to consciously st…

contributors.bio: A model finding her way back to writing

post.title: Two selves
post.description: I wish I could put the two distinct ways I show up online into a blender and serve them like a perfectly balanced smoothie.
post.truncated_body_text: I wish I could put the two distinct ways I show up online into a blender and serve them like a perfectly balanced smoothie. The content creator and the writer, made up of pleasing aesthetics and meaningful thoughts, bright notes and dark hues. Maybe it’s difficult because one self has never existed online until now.

post.title: Unpause
post.truncated_body_text: Writing is hard. Actually it’s not hard so much as it’s scary. I haven’t been vulnerable in such a long time. At least not in the way I used to be.

comment.name: Mina Le
comment.body: one of the saddest things about the internet and how it’s devolved thus far is no one can read sarcasm anymore! no one understands jokes! i could repost a funny little meme of sabrina carpenter quoting karl marx and someone would go “just wanted to let you know that she never actually said that!” painful times we live in.

content.text: one of the saddest things about the internet and how it’s devolved thus far is no one can read sarcasm anymore! no one understands jokes! i could repost a funny little meme of sabrina carpenter quoting karl marx and someone would go “just wanted to let you know that she never actually said that!” painful times we live in.

post.title: Navigating Parenthood with EDS: Genetic Risk, Ethical Considerations, and IVF
post.subtitle: Discussing complex personal choices when it comes to pregnancy
post.description: Discussing complex personal choices when it comes to pregnancy
post.truncated_body_text: In case you missed it - I’m expecting! And I am eager to share this journey with all of you. I recently asked what topics you would like me to discuss when it comes to pregnancy and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) or chronic illness in general. One of the most requested topics so far was conversations around having biological children with a known risk of …

post.title: EDS and Pregnancy: Myth vs. Fact
post.subtitle: Discussing common "myths" surrounding Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome and Pregnancy
post.description: Discussing common "myths" surrounding Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome and Pregnancy
post.truncated_body_text: Navigating pregnancy with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) can be challenging, especially with the many misconceptions surrounding the condition. This blog post aims to debunk some simple, common myths about EDS and pregnancy. Whether you're planning a pregnancy or just curious, understanding the facts can help empower individuals with EDS to make informed …

post.title: Inclusive Workplaces and Academic Environments
post.subtitle: Discussing accommodations for disabled students and scientists
post.description: Discussing accommodations for disabled students and scientists
post.truncated_body_text: When it comes to education and the workplace, creating an inclusive environment where everyone can thrive is essential. For disabled individuals, accommodations can make all the difference in setting them up for success. However, one of the hardest parts of requesting accommodations is knowing exactly what to ask for—especially when these needs can vary…
